title: R44430
content: The Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) administers programs under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) to improve criminal justice responses to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for OVW was $489 million, with proposed increases for various grants and initiatives. The Obama Administration proposed funding initiatives to address domestic violence, including reducing firearm lethality and enhancing responses to campus sexual assault. Congress adopted a $326 million transfer for OVW from the Crime Victims Fund but did not fully support other proposals. Funding for grants to encourage arrests in domestic violence cases and strengthen tribal justice systems' response to domestic violence was increased, but not at the level proposed. STOP grants funding was not reduced for FY2017. The Obama Administration proposed increased funding for STOP grants, but Congress did not support the proposal for FY2017. The Office of Justice Programs manages various grant programs, including the Bureau of Justice Statistics and the National Institute of Justice. The Administration requested a 32.8% increase in funding for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account for FY2017. The Administration proposed increased funding for the Institute of Justice and forensic sciences improvement program, as well as new initiatives for evidence-based programs and crime statistics. Congress provided $89 million for the Research, Evaluation, and Statistics account for FY2017, with a decrease in funding due to the transfer of funds for the Regional Information Sharing System. The State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account includes grants for various criminal justice programs. The Obama Administration's FY2017 request for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance was $1.098 billion, 22.1% less than FY2016. Proposed cuts included State Criminal Alien Assistance Program, Paul Coverdell Forensic Sciences Improvement Program, grants for trafficking victims, John R. Justice program, and tribal assistance program. Funding for grants to assist trafficking victims would come from the Crime Victims Fund. Additionally, 7% of funding would support tribal justice programs, with a reduction in funding for the JAG program. The Obama Administration proposed reducing funding for various programs under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account, including the JAG program, National Criminal History Improvement program, and DNA backlog reduction initiatives. However, they also suggested increasing funding for reentry initiatives, programs for children exposed to violence, grants for substance abuse treatment, and programs for individuals with mental illness in the criminal justice system. Additionally, new programs were requested, such as the Byrne Incentive Grant program. The Byrne Incentive Grant program received $15 million for supplemental grants to JAG program grantees supporting evidence-based initiatives. $20 million was allocated for grants to improve fairness in the justice system and build community trust. $5 million was designated for the Violence Reduction Network to develop data-driven strategies, and $6 million for grants to counter violent extremism. Funding for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance was reduced by 9.1% for FY2017. Funding for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance was reduced by 9.1% for FY2017, with a $128 million decrease. Congress also reduced top-line funding for the JAG program by $73 million. Funding for tribal assistance programs was eliminated, but DOJ can use up to 7% of funding for tribal justice assistance programs. $103 million was provided for an opioid initiative under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account. Congress provided $103 million for an opioid initiative under the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance account, with funding coming from various existing programs. An additional $13 million was allocated for programs authorized by the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act of 2016. New programs proposed by the Obama Administration were not funded, and the Juvenile Justice Programs account includes funding for grant programs to reduce juvenile delinquency. The Obama Administration proposed a $334 million budget for Juvenile Justice Programs in FY2017, a 23.8% increase from the previous year. The proposal included funding increases for various programs like JJDPA Part B formula grants, Title V grants, and the Community-based Violence Prevention Initiative. Additionally, funding was requested for the restoration of Juvenile Accountability Block Grants and a Smart on Juvenile Justice Initiative. Funding cuts were proposed for youth mentoring grants and investigation/prosecution of child abuse programs. Congress appropriated $247 million for the Juvenile Justice Programs account for FY2017, with reductions in funding for youth mentoring grants, investigation and prosecution of child abuse programs, and the missing and exploited children program. Funding cuts were also made for JJDPA Part B state formula grants, Title V grants, and new programs proposed by the Obama Administration were not funded. The Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) Office awards grants for law enforcement agencies to hire new officers, train them in community policing, and develop innovative policing strategies. The Obama Administration requested a $74 million increase in funding for the COPS program in FY2017, with a focus on hiring new officers, training in community policing, and deploying crime-fighting technologies. Congress appropriated $222 million for the COPS account, including a $3 million increase for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program. Funding for the COPS hiring program remained unchanged at $137 million after set-asides. In FY2017, Congress increased funding for the Anti-heroin Task Forces program and transferred funding from the Regional Information Sharing System to OJP. $8 million was set aside from the COPS hiring program for the POLICE Act of 2016, allowing grants for active shooter training. The Administration requested $500 million for the 21st Century Justice Initiative, a new program aimed at criminal justice reform efforts. This initiative would have focused on reducing crime, unnecessary incarceration, and building community trust through innovative approaches. States could use the funding to address various objectives in their adult and juvenile systems. States could have used funding to focus on objectives such as changing laws for shorter sentences, community policing advancements, and providing diversion and reentry services. 10% of the funding would have been dedicated to federal criminal justice reform efforts. However, Congress did not provide funding for this program.
